==Meta-ethics==
 
==Meta-ethics==
 
{{Main|Meta-ethics}}
 
{{Main|Meta-ethics}}
−
Meta-ethics is a field within philosophy that seeks to understand the nature of [[normative ethics]]. The focus of meta-ethics is on how we understand, know about, and what we mean when we talk about what is right and what is wrong.
+
Meta-ethics is a field within philosophy that seeks to understand the nature of [[non-normative ethics]]. The focus of meta-ethics is on how we understand, know about, and what we mean when we talk about what is right and what is wrong.
     
Meta-ethics has always accompanied philosophical ethics, but in this explicit sense it came to the fore with [[George Edward Moore|G.E. Moore]]'s ''[[Principia Ethica]]'' from 1903. In it he first wrote about what he called ''the [[naturalistic fallacy]]''. Moore was seen to reject [[Ethical naturalism|naturalism]] in ethics, in his [[Open Question Argument]]. This made thinkers look again at second order questions about ethics. Earlier, the Scottish [[philosopher]] [[David Hume]] had put forward a similar view on the difference between [[Is-ought problem|facts and values]].
 
Meta-ethics has always accompanied philosophical ethics, but in this explicit sense it came to the fore with [[George Edward Moore|G.E. Moore]]'s ''[[Principia Ethica]]'' from 1903. In it he first wrote about what he called ''the [[naturalistic fallacy]]''. Moore was seen to reject [[Ethical naturalism|naturalism]] in ethics, in his [[Open Question Argument]]. This made thinkers look again at second order questions about ethics. Earlier, the Scottish [[philosopher]] [[David Hume]] had put forward a similar view on the difference between [[Is-ought problem|facts and values]].
